unnormalised: ## Training Regimens: What works best? (Sports Category)
normalised: ## Training Regimens: What works best? (Sports Category)

unnormalised: Okay, so you're serious about your sport, whether it's cricket like Kohli or badminton like Sindhu? Good! But just talent won't cut it. You need a solid training regimen.
normalised: Okay, so you are serious about your sport, whether it is cricket like Kohli or badminton like Sindhu? Good! But just talent won't cut it. You need a solid training regimen.

unnormalised: I've seen folks try all sorts of things. Some go for the old-school approach: endless laps at the Nehru Stadium in Delhi, running 5 km before breakfast. Others are all about the fancy new methods they saw online, like plyometrics and interval training.
normalised: I have seen folks try all sorts of things. Some go for the old-school approach: endless laps at the Nehru Stadium in Delhi, running five kilometer before breakfast. Others are all about the fancy new methods they saw online, like plyometrics and interval training.

unnormalised: Honestly, what works *best* depends on you. Your sport, your body, your goals. A marathon runner in Chennai needs a different plan than a kabaddi player from Patna.
normalised: Honestly, what works *best* depends on you. Your sport, your body, your goals. A marathon runner in Chennai needs a different plan than a kabaddi player from Patna.

unnormalised: My advice? Start with the basics. Strength training, cardio, and sport-specific drills. Don’t skip the warm-up! Think of it as a puja before you begin. Then, gradually increase the intensity. Get a good coach! They can tailor a plan for you, taking into account things like rest days and nutrition.
normalised: My advice? Start with the basics. Strength training, cardio, and sport-specific drills. Don't skip the warm-up! Think of it as a puja before you begin. Then, gradually increase the intensity. Get a good coach! They can tailor a plan for you, taking into account things like rest days and nutrition.

unnormalised: Remember Sharmaji’s son, Rohan? He thought he could just wing it before his cricket trials at the NCA. He was burnt out by 10:00 hrs on 26/01/2023 and didn’t even make the cut.
normalised: Remember Sharmaji’s son, Rohan? He thought he could just wing it before his cricket trials at the N C A. He was burnt out by ten zero zero hours on twenty sixth january two thousand and twenty three and didn’t even make the cut.

unnormalised: Listen to your body. Don't push yourself too hard, especially when you're starting out or coming back from an injury. Rest is just as important as training.
normalised: Listen to your body. Don't push yourself too hard, especially when you are starting out or coming back from an injury. Rest is just as important as training.

unnormalised: Experiment a bit to see what your body responds to. Track your progress – jot down your timings, weights, and how you feel after each session. A simple notebook will do! This will help you adjust your plan as needed. You might find that a morning run on 15/08/1947 (a truly patriotic start!) sets you up perfectly for the day. Or maybe evening practice after your B.Com classes works better.

unnormalised: Finally, consistency is key. Aim for regular training sessions, even if they're just short ones. A little bit every day is better than a lot once a week. Just like your grandma says, "Boond boond se ghada bharta hai!" Now go get 'em!
